HIRING CONTACT: Robert (Bob) Gottfried, (512) 389-8744 PHYSICAL WORK ADDRESS: TPWD Headquarters, 4200 Smith School Road, Austin, TX 78744 GENERAL DESCRIPTION: Under the supervision of the Texas Natural Diversity Database (TXNDD) Administrator, the TXNDD Developer will develop, implement, and maintain innovative systems for collecting, managing, analyzing, and distributing complex data to inform conservation planning. Performs advanced (senior-level) geographic information systems (GIS) work. Specifically, the TXNDD Developer will develop electronic data collection tools to streamline data collection and data entry workflow. This position will develop data products to maximize the analytical and conservation value of TXNDD data and facilitate efficient and effective data consumption and use by internal and external users. In addition to the TXNDD, the position will participate in the development and maintenance of other Texas Parks and Wildlife Department (TPWD) databases that contribute to the function and goals of TPWD natural resources divisions and programs. The TXNDD Developer will coordinate with TPWD staff to ensure data needs and priorities are being met and identify opportunities for collaboration in the development of conservation data products and robust data analyses. Works under minimal supervision, with considerable latitude for the use of initiative and independent judgment. Performs other duties as assigned. Complies with all Agency, Division and Branch rules, regulations and procedures. Qualifications MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS: Education: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor’s degree in Geographic Information Science (GIS), Geospatial Analysis, Geography with an emphasis in GIS, Wildlife Biology, Wildlife Management, Ecology, or related biological field with major coursework in wildlife/plant/habitat conservation, management, or research; Three semesters of course work in GIS and/or statistics with at least two semesters of GIS. Experience: Six months of experience collecting and/or managing biological/ecological data using GIS or a non-spatial relational database, ideally including experience with species or ecosystem observation data and/or habitat suitability (species distribution) models; Experience maintaining and querying spatial and non-spatial databases. Licensure: Must possess or be able to obtain, within 30 days of employment, a valid Class “C” Texas driver’s license. NOTE: Retention of position contingent upon obtaining and maintaining required license. ACCEPTABLE SUBSTITUTIONS: Education: One year of experience using GIS to manage and analyze biological/ecological data in a graduate school or professional setting can substitute for two semesters of GIS coursework. PREFERRED QUALIFICATIONS: Education: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Master’s degree in GIS, Geospatial Analysis, Geography with an emphasis in GIS, Wildlife Biology, Wildlife Management, Ecology, or related biological field with major coursework in wildlife/plant/habitat conservation, management, or research. Experience: Demonstrated experience independently analyzing spatial data, including developing innovative approaches to solve complex problems, and improving and documenting spatial data processes; Demonstrated experience applying ESRI technology (e.g., ArcGIS Pro, ArcGIS Online, Survey123, ArcGIS Field Maps) for the collection, management, or analysis of spatial data; Demonstrated experience using R to develop habitat suitability and species distribution models; Demonstrated experience in using Python to script ArcGIS-based processes; One year of experience and demonstrated skills in gathering, documenting, and implementing user requirements as part of application development. KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES Knowledge of GIS and relational database principles; Knowledge of basic wildlife research and data collection techniques including use of GPS hardware; Knowledge of Texas species of concern as identified in the Texas Conservation Action Plan, including threatened and endangered species status, habitat, and life history; Knowledge of NatureServe and Natural Heritage Network methodology and standards; Skill in using GIS (ESRI products), GPS, and common PC software applications; Skill in the use of electronic field data collection tools (e.g., Survey123, ArcGIS Field Maps) Skill in using database applications, database data entry, and developing and manipulating databases and database reports; Skill in interpreting spatial biological data; Skill in the use of data analysis software (e.g., Kaleidoscope); Skill in training others; Skill in collaborating, cooperating, and working effectively with others as part of a multi-disciplined team to develop, plan, design, and devise solutions to technical problems; Skill in organization, including attention to detail and an ability to independently manage tasks and ensure timely completion of project deliverables; Ability to write code in Python, R, SQL, or other coding languages; Ability to work independently with little direct supervision; Ability and desire to work as part of a team to accomplish tasks; Ability to prioritize and accomplish multiple assigned tasks and to manage time effectively; Ability to communicate effectively with a diverse group of people including academics, conservation professionals, and the general public; Ability to present to an audience in a work or conference setting; Ability to develop, plan, design, and devise solutions to technical or analytical problems; Ability to conduct work activities in accordance with TPWD safety program. WORKING CONDITIONS: Required to work from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm, Monday through Friday; This position is suitable to telework two days per week and the candidate may be allowed to telework with supervisor approval; Must conform to TPWD dress and grooming standards, work rules, and safety procedures; Required to travel 5% with possible overnight stays; May be required to operate a State vehicle; Non-smoking environment in State buildings and vehicles.
